CatDescriptText: Maude Y. Jones, housewife, Homewood and Louise Robinson, housewife, North Side, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, April 22, 1961, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think that Negroes, when unable to obtain a 'square deal,' in politics, should register a 'protest' vote by voting for Negro candidates on a ticket, or should they utilize other tactics to protest and continue to vote for all candidates who are qualified and will serve their interests best?" Maude Y. Jones' answer reads: "We should judge candidates by the qualifications...But by living in the 13th Ward, my sympathy is with the colored candidates.  I don't think they are receiving a square deal under the present political set-up in the city..."  Louise Robinson's answer reads: "I believe all colored neighborhoods should run their own areas so that Negroes can receive a square deal...And if the leaders, voted into office, do not stick to their promises, then they should be voted out."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Maude Y. Jones wearing patterned neck scarf and light colored coat, holding gloves and bag, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Louise Robinson with eyes closed wearing light colored coat, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Thrift Drugs in background, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
